results.title: Picturesque Tasmania
results.creator_credit: G Gamon and Australia. Dept of Commerce. Cinema Branch
results.brief_description: Produced by the Cinema Branch, Australian Department of Commerce. A driving tour of Tasmania from Hobart along the western, northern, eastern and southern coasts focussing on the natural scenery. A number of towns and their various industries can also be seen such as trout hatcheries, the Mt Lyell mine, hops and apple growing. Source: NFSA Film Australia Collection.

results.title: Spectacle Talks: Gotye and his Collaborators
results.creator_credit: Gotye, Mike Kenneally, Shelley Matulick, Kim Montgomery and ACMI
results.brief_description:
Multi award-winning musician, songwriter and producer Gotye is no stranger to collaboration. His music videos are a testament to this, utilising the talents of diverse directors, artists and animators. Often involving a range of complex animation and filmmaking techniques, visual worlds are created floating seamlessly against his music.
Natasha Pincus, Andrew Goldsmith, and directors of Rubber House animation studio Ivan Dixon and Greg Sharp disscus a selection of Gotye’s most renowned videos. These include ‘Easy Way Out’, ‘Seven Hours With A Back Seat Driver’, ‘State Of The Art’ and the international chart-topping ‘Somebody That I Used To Know’.
Hosted by film and music critic Megan Spencer, this event provided a fascinating insight into the collaborative journey, from initial concept and creative development, through to final clip production.

results.title: Spectacle Director Showcase: Natasha Pincus
results.creator_credit: Mike Kenneally, Shelley Matulick, Kim Montgomery and ACMI
results.brief_description:
Natasha Pincus is a multi award winning Australian music video director and producer and has won the ARIA award for Best Music Video two years in a row. Her stop motion animation video for Gotye’s ‘Somebody That I Used to Know’ has had a staggering 420 million views. Natasha talks about getting her first big break making a music video for Paul Kelly.

Created as part of “Spectacle : The Music Video Exhibition” 26 September 2013 - 23 February 2014. ACMI Digital Programs worked with Exhibitions to interview five Australian directors featured in the exhibition about the art and techniques of music video production.

results.title: Spectacle Director Showcase: Oh Yeah Wow
results.creator_credit: Sam Mapplebeck, Shelley Matulick, Kim Montgomery and ACMI
results.brief_description:
‘Oh Yeah Wow’ are a Melbourne based creative collective that make music videos, short films and TV programs. In this interview directors Darcy Prendergast, Seamus Spilsbury and Josh Thomas discuss music videos.

Created as part of “Spectacle : The Music Video Exhibition” 26 September 2013 - 23 February 2014. ACMI Digital Programs worked with Exhibitions to interview five Australian directors featured in the exhibition about the art and techniques of music video production.

results.title: Would You Like to Fly?
results.creator_credit: John Kingsford-Smith, Kingcroft Productions and Australia. Dept. of the Interior. Film Division
results.brief_description:
This film was produced by John Kingsford-Smith, nephew of the renowned aviator Charles Kingsford-Smith. John Kingsford-Smith became a successful and prolific producer of documentaries from 1948 to the 1980s. During this time he produced 327 sponsored films and commercials and played a key creative role in all of them (as writer, director, cinematographer or editor).

This film is a combination of his two passions, aviation and filmmaking; one may wonder how many people were spurred on to learn how to fly after watching this film!

results.title: Spectacle Talks: Hello Flux Panel Discussion
results.creator_credit: Sam Mapplebeck, Shelley Matulick, Kim Montgomery and ACMI
results.brief_description:
A special panel discussion held at ACMI on 26th September 2013. Exhibition curators Jonathan Wells and Meg Grey Wells joined an extended panel that included Alexei Tylevich (the designer of ‘Spectacle: The Music Video Exhibition’) and Australian music video directors Darcy Prendergast, Josh Thomas, Luci Schroder and Kris Moyes.
Moderated by ACMI curator Amita Kirpalani, the panel discusses the exhibition, personal experiences in production and the art of the music video. Filmed as part of ‘Spectacle: The Music Video Exhibition’ 26 September 2013 - 23 February 2014.

results.title: Spectacle: Interview with Curators Jonathan Wells and Meg Grey Wells
results.creator_credit: Mike Kenneally, Shelley Matulick, Kim Montgomery and ACMI
results.brief_description:
“How many exhibitions would have the range of Bob Dylan to Kanye West?” (Jonathan Wells)
Flux Curators Jonathan Wells and Meg Grey Wells share what inspired ‘Spectacle: The Music Video Exhibition’, the challenges in bringing over 300 clips into an exhibition context and their favourite areas in the exhibition.
Created as part of ‘Spectacle: The Music Video Exhibition’ 26 September 2013 - 23 February 2014.

results.title: Among the Hardwoods
results.creator_credit: Lyn Maplestone and Commonwealth of Australia
results.brief_description: An earlier silent version of this film was made in 1927 as part of the ‘Know Your Own Country’ series by renowned pioneer cinematographer Lacey Percival. In mid-1936 Bert Ive and a sound recordist revisited the Pemberton region of south-west Western Australia where they filmed and also recorded natural sounds from the forest. Whilst this re-edited film was half the length of the original, Ive’s director Lyn Maplestone created greater impact by lingering on the sights and sounds of logging trees in the Jarrah and Karri forests. The film focuses on the atmosphere of the forest as it was irrevocably changed by the axe and saw of the loggers. Scenes shot for the silent version (but not always used) can also be seen being processed and screened in ‘Telling the World’ (1929). Source: NFSA Film Australia Collection.

results.title: Telling the World
results.brief_description: As the title suggests, ‘Telling The World’ was made for an overseas audience as was much of the Government film unit’s output. It covers the roles and functions of the Cinema and Photographic Branch and shows Bert Ive filming some of the iconic images he would capture of important Australian events and places. The opening sequence shows a meeting between the Cinema Branch’s Officer-in-Charge Lyn Maplestone and Bert Ive, who appear periodically throughout the film. Ive continued to work for the branch until his death in 1939. The film has been sepia toned, a specialised chemical treatment enhancing black and white film with a warmer tone. Some scenes in the processing laboratory are tinted red. An excellent example of the period’s documentary and innovative filmmaking techniques. Source: NFSA Film Australia Collection.
